comments.text:
+Grace Liu "whatcha got to prevent the Breadbasket Midwest states from 
tripling the price of all the food they grow?"
Someone somewhere in the world would pick up their market share. Prior to 
the American civil war, the American south absolutely dominated cotton. 
This changed quickly after a Union blockade cut off the south. At first 
there was a cotton shortage. Then there was an explosive growth in cotton 
production in India and Egypt.

Going further, the most powerful Midwestern States (agriculture, industry, 
and population) are clustered around the Great Lakes or would be in that 
general sphere of influence (Iowa). While Chicago would be a logical 
capital for this grouping, the state of Illinois wouldn't necessarily be 
more dominant than either Ohio or Michigan.

This group's priorities would be:
1. Enforce Right of free passage on the Mississippi river (A major grain 
export route) and Saint Lawrence seaway.
2. Place Kentucky and West Virginia in their sphere of influence for coal 
and energy resources.

This would place them in conflict with the South and not the Northeast 
(which has some overlapping interests with them).

comments.text:
+jpheitman As I mentioned, someone said "kick[s] ass," so I used "spank." XD

Anyway, I like how you analyzed about the Vietnam War and its "wars," but I 
think in the end both countries lost, at least in a long-term manner. Yeah, 
I know it's weird and I'm horrible at explaining. After all, the Vietnam 
War was more of a civil war. "The Second Vietnam War," as you referred to 
it, the United States possibly had achieved its goal of aiding South 
Vietnam, but two years later the Republic of Vietnam collapsed, so I would 
say it was a temporary victory for the U.S.

Also, while North Vietnam recognized South Vietnam's sovereignty on paper, 
and the Republic was recognized by countries like UK, US,...the Communist 
states (Ex. Russia) have recognized its communist comrade - North Vietnam. 
Considering its withdrawal a year after the peace accords, the USA had 
possibly realized that its intervention will not successfully alter the 
result.

The other thing is that the Socialist Republic of Vietnam might be 
considered the victor, but Vietnam was horribly drained by colonialism, as 
a result it is now impoverished, corrupted, and hierarchical. As many 
communist states will become, "Independence-Freedom-Happiness" became the 
opposite. In the end, the U.S remained a developed state; many Southern 
Vietnamese of 1975 moved to the States as refugees and established their 
well-beings, while Vietnam became what it has became: a poor country. In my 
viewpoint, there is no definite answer to the question "Which side won the 
Vietnam War?"

Everyone is welcomed to inform me more about this topic. 

+Thừa An Đặng, just as any person who doesn't see both sides of the 
problem, is terribly supportive of North Vietnam, and that is fine. I lived 
in Vietnam for most of my life, and I wouldn't stand it when people (who 
clearly have no clue) start talking about the Vietnam War and how bad 
Vietnam is. Government officials are extremely corrupted, and they do not 
fear to show it, but as watup2101 mentioned: Don't judge a country by its

comments.text:
+Ivy Nguyen Really? The guy named +Thừa An Đặng is Vietnamese?!? Would 
never have guessed that -_-

Also, contrary to popular belief, the U.S. did not "get spanked" in 
Vietnam. The U.S. engaged in a limited war in Vietnam, successfully 
preventing the North from absorbing the South for over decade and a half, 
while not getting China committed like it did in Korea. There was no end in 
sight until the Tet offensive; after that, the U.S. had practically won, as 
the NLF was nearly annihilated. Eventually, by 1972, peace accords were 
signed where North Vietnam officially recognized the sovereignty of South 
Vietnam, without either party losing territory. That was the intended 
result, so the U.S. did, in fact, win the Second Vietnam "War." The U.S. 
then pulled out a year later. 

Two years after THAT, the North declared war on the South again, and the 
U.S. did not intervene. *That* war, the Third Vietnam "War," was a decisive 
victory for the North Vietnamese; South Vietnam didn't stand a chance. 

Whatever the result, it's noteworthy that the U.S. was supporting half of 
the Vietnamese against the other half. It's ridiculous to say, therefore, 
that +Thừa An Đặng was definitively against the U.S. Hell, he probably 
wasn't even alive back then! 

P.S. The First Vietnam "War" was the one with the French, who 
(unsurprisingly) lost, especially after the spectacular defeat at Điện Biên 
Phủ.

+gamer263 I dunno... It seems to me that the A-bomb is, like, the best 
invention EVER. Without it, the U.S. and U.S.S.R. would have had a very, 
very, VERY deadly conventional war some time in the '50s or '60s. The only 
thing that stopped the conventional war was the threat of instant 
annihilation by atomic fire, and death by fire is possibly the most 
horrific (terrestrial) death imaginable.

Besides that, if the Hiroshima bomb wasn't dropped, the U.S. would have had 
to launch an amphibious assault on Japan, which would have cost lots of 
U.S. servicemen their lives, along with lots and lots of Japanese soldiers, 
and absolute boatloads of Japanese civilians. Casualty estimates from the 
time predicted ~500,000 U.S. military casualties, ~2-3 million Japanese 
military casualties, and ~2-10 million Japanese civilian casualties - far 
greater than the ~150,000 killed by the Hiroshima bomb. 

The Nagasaki bomb is rather more ambiguous, as the Hiroshima one alone 
might have secured Japan's surrender.

All in all, though, the A-bomb has saved far, FAR more lives than it has 
taken. 

Thanks for reading this essay. :P

comments.text:
+matt kelly I'm reminded of a story about a gardener and a caterpillar.  A 
caterpillar took to eating the gardener's bean plants one day.  Every day, 
the gardener would find signs of the caterpillar but never the caterpillar. 
 Eventually, the caterpillar became complacent, eating more and more 
thinking he was safe from the gardener.  One day, tired and belly filled to 
satisfaction, the caterpillar decided to spin his cocoon.  He found he had 
eaten all the foliage around him and had grown too fat and lazy to find a 
suitable place to hide.  Sure he would never be found, he spun it in the 
open.  Later that evening, a passing bird found the cocoon with the 
caterpillar tuck away in it.  The caterpillar became a good meal for the 
bird.  The moral of the story: become conceited, fat, lazy, confident of 
your status and security in an insecure world, misuse your resources, you 
get your ass handed to you.  That's the situation America is in right now. 
 Americans might have believed in the back of their minds a terror attack 
was possible but they never saw 9/11 coming.  In situations like that, 
technology fails you and your "social contract" doesn't mean shit.

speak it, or just letting Puerto Rico be in the language department and 
effectively vindicating the people on the mainland that refuse to 
assimilate.  Either way you slice it, it's just not going to happen.

every once in a while is very doable.

mean its pretty embarrassing that the government is so paranoid at

comments.text:
Finally, someone who takes a logical examination and analysis of the United 
States before being rude about it. Most people in other countries always 
stereotype the United States as stupid, interfering, arrogant, and rude to 
Native Americans, but that isn't all totally true. Sure, we did treat the 
Native Americans poorly, but most of that was during the Andrew Jackson 
era, and we frown upon that policy today. Most of the hostility toward the 
natives were actually the Europeans when they settled here. Second, perhaps 
our math scores are low compared to other countries, and our education 
isn't too well, but that doesn't make us all stupid. There are quite a bit 
of intelligent people in the USA. Also, we aren't 'Kill and Conquer' like 
many other nations would like to believe. After all, many European empires 
long before the country's founding conquered and stretched their borders 
across the world. I'm an American, and proud of it, no one could ever 
convince me to hate my country, but we have our faults, but we aren't like 
what other countries think. So, I just have to thank you so much for being 
the first person to logically analyze the USA before coming to a conclusion 
about it.

comments.text:
Empire has a very simple definition

an extensive group of states or countries ruled over by a single monarch, 
an oligarchy, or a sovereign state.

an extensive sphere of activity controlled by one person or group.

The Commonwealth is an empire, the Warsaw Pact and the USSR's sphere of 
influence is an empire, NATO and the EU are the 'western empires' due to 
how centralized they are and the UK, France, Germany, USA, China and Russia 
still have their own empires which rule over large swathes of land that 
they took from other people.

Apple or BAE Systems are corporate empires, possessing control over funding 
and capital rather than sovereign land. 

Churches such as the Catholic Church of the Vatican represent remaining 
Theocratic empire, and still the Catholic church holds massive power over 
land, resources and capital today. Though the Catholic church is more like 
a corporation with the Pope as it's CEO than anything else.

When we're talking about countries, a nation which expends it's will 
regularly on other native or foreign populations, owns and seeks to control 
territory well outside of it's native bounds, a country that has 
infrastructure based systems that spread across continents and the world to 
retain control over other nations, a nation which uses both economic and 
military might to suppress potential adversaries. A nation that owns 
aircraft carriers, a worldwide network of air bases and nuclear facilities.

Yeah, countries like those in NATO, the USA and Russia/China are most 
certainly empires.

comments.text:
+Gorilder Hawaii is different because it has a successful economy & much 
smaller population. It can be more dependent on tourism since it attracts 
both Californians and Japanese/Chinese. It's an understatement to say 
Puerto Rico's is "not the greatest". It is abysmal, much poorer than the 
poorest US state. It has never been self sufficient in modern history, 
depending on tax breaks for US corporations that have now been ended by the 
IRS, sending PR into a recession. It's government is in major debt. It has 
no resources besides sugar, coffee, and some fruit, all of which are 
inadequate to either feed or provide enough export trade for the population 
of nearly 4 million. All this is why tens of thousands leave PR each year 
to move to the USA due to the consistent decline in jobs, a decline that 
will only worsen as tax shelters for US corporations have been removed. The 
flow of Puerto Ricans immigrating is all that is keeping the island afloat.

decision for Congress and the people of Puerto Rico

captions.text: The United States is, shockingly, a bunch of states that are united.
It was just 13 to start with,
but as time marched on, the border marked west,

bringing us to today and the 48 contiguous states
plus Alaska and Hawaii.

They're usually drawn in these little boxes,
not to to scale because Hawaii is in the middle of a

vast ocean of deadly nothing-ness, 
and Alaska is monstrous.

Unlike other unions, where members can leave
if they so choose,
statehood is eternal.
Even for you, Texas.

Now, how the federal government works 
is a story for another time,

but at the moment, all you need know is that
Congress, where national laws are written

is made of representatives who are sent 
from the states.

Now, there are some non-state gaps not
visible on this map.

The first is Washington D.C.,
the nation's capital.

which is a stateless limbo land
between Maryland and Virginia.

As D.C. is a city without a state,
it puts her under the control of Congress.

Meaning all the other states get the final
say on how D.C. is run,
while she doesn't get a vote in anything.

It didn't matter when the District of Columbia
was basically uninhabited,

but since more people live in D.C. now
than do in a couple of states
it's an uncomfortable arrangement.

The other gaps on this map are the 
American Indian reservations.
which are numerous.

The United States kind of administers them
while sort of  treating them as foreign nations

which means you could draw the state
boundaries to look like this

because the reservations are kind of
apart from those states.

But the American Indian reservations
are such a full of asterisks
(O' so sensitive situation)

it's also better as a story for
another time.

Gaps aside, the continent (and Hawaii) is
mostly straight-forward.

But there's more than just these
United States.

When the U.S. ran out of lands 
to manifest destiny,

she learned from the best
and teritorified a whole bunch of islands.

First up: Puerto Rico - 
an organized, unincorporated territory

of the U.S.
This means she's self-governing(to some extent)

and that all the U.S. constitution doesn't 
automatically apply

on the island.
Now, 3.7 million people live in Puerto Rico

which is 91% of the people living
on U.S. Territorial islands

and more people than live in
21 of the states.

And, the U.S. treats Puerto Rico
as a state in almost all but name

which possibly soon
she will be anyway

bringing the number of stars to a 
nice, even, 51?

But Puerto Rico isn't the only
organized, unincorporated territory.

There's also Guam, which was acquired
in the Spanish-American war,

along with Puerto Rico, there's 
the Northern Mariana Islands,
taken from Japan during World War II,

and the U.S. Virgin Islands taken from
nobody -- Denmark sold her.

The people in these territories are 
American citizens.

In most ways, the territories are
just like D.C.

Congress can override their
local governments and they don't have
representation because no state-tation.
But otherwise, it's America.

Actually, the territories and D.C. do 
get to elect congressional representatives
who attend all of the meetings
but just can't vote in any of them.

which is either the worst job in the world
or the best job in the world
depending on the kind of person who gets it.

Also, since votes for president are based
on state population,
citizens in the territories can't vote.

Which as mentioned in a previous video
leads to the weird situation that

Americans who live in foreign countries
can vote for president in the
state where they last lived.

While Americans who live in America,
just in a territory,
cannot.

Along with these unincorporated organized
territories

there are also unincorporated unorganized
territories.
Actually, quite a few.

They are Howland Island,
Navassa Island,
Wake Island, Jarvis Island,

Johnston Atoll, Kingman Reef,
Midway Reef,
Serranilla Bank and Bajo Nuevo Bank.

Most of these were acquired under the 
delightfully named Guano Islands Act

when the U.S. decided she wanted
a bunch of islands filled with bird poop.

No, really, the U.S. just straight up
wrote a law to declare those islands
were now hers.

Unorganized, in this system, means there's
no local government on these islands
because no one lives in these places.
Some of them are barley above the water line.

Now, the weird category is unorganized 
incorporated territories
of which there is one: the Palmyra Atoll.

claimed by the U.S. after the totally
peaceful annexation of Hawaii.

They're currently an uninhabited 
nature reserve.

But, incorporated means the U.S.
constitution applies here.

To who? The Palmyra Atoll is like that 
question about a tree falling in the forest.

If there are no people for the constitution
to apply to,
does the constitution still apply?
Yes.

This means if a foreigner gives birth
on this uninhabited strip
and doesn't die from the nature,
their child would be an American citizen.
Now, this category is empty.

It's where territories go
before they become states.

When basically the Constitution fully
applies
and it was last occupied by Hawaii.

We've gone full circle but there is
one territory we've left out --
American Samoa: home to 55,000 people.

Uniquely, American Samoans 
don't get to be citizens
but instead are American Nationals.

They can live in the states but can't vote
in presidential elections

Unless they go through the immigration
process like any foreigner.

Even though in all other ways,
they're indistinguishable from citizens.

This is unique to American Samoa
and there seems to be no reason for it

other than that Congress has
gotten around to updating the system.

American Samoa is in the 
no-government category, like it's lord of the flies
over there, which it obviously isn't.

So American Samoa with it's organized 
government needs to go over here and

Puerto Rico, essentially a state, 
needs to go over here

and the empty Palmyra Atoll needs to go
over here.

But, don't hold your breath for the
paperwork to make it's way through Congress
any time soon.

So, that's all the territories of the 
United States, but there is one final

thing to talk about: three tiny nations --
Palu, the Marshall Islands and the
Federated States of Micronesia.

The last has a convenient domain name: .fm --
first choice of quality podcasts everywhere.
*hint, hint; click, click*

These are separate countries
with UN seats and everything

but they have a 
"Compact of Free Association"
with the United States.

The deal is that the U.S. provide economic
support and military defense to the

compact nations in return for being allowed
to build military bases there.

Also, compact citizens can live and work
in the United States and vice versa.

The Americans wanting to live abroad:
you have three easy options.

So, that's America: 50 states,
many reservations, one district,

lots of islands territories, some even 
with people and three tiny associated countries.
